V1C0L10: For a simpler version of the game, remove cards #10, #14, #15 and #41.
V1C0L15: All the cards are in your hands!
V1C0L6: You need one deck of Climate Fresk cards per team (4 to 7 people),  a 36'' x 80'' piece of paper, pencils, erasers, colored markers, and tape.
V1C0L7: The goal is for each team to place the cards on the table in approximate order of cause and effect, find the relationships among the cards, and, eventually, draw arrows between the cards to illustrate how the various aspects of climate change are interrelated.
V1C0L8: Distribute the cards set by set. You will distribute and discuss the cards in each set before moving on to the next set.
V1C0L9: Workshop components: 90 minutes to play the five-round card game, 20-30 minutes to decorate the Fresk and present the results, 10 minutes to debrief our feelings, and then 45-60 minutes to discuss the levers of action.
V1C10L2: Aerosols are tiny polluting particles that come from the incomplete combustion of fossil fuels. Aerosols are a danger for human health and have a negative contribution to radiative forcing (they cool the climate). Despite what it seems, "aerosols" have nothing to do with spray cans.
V1C11L2: About half of our CO2 emissions are absorbed by natural carbon sinks. The other half remains in the atmosphere. The concentration of CO2 in the air has increased from 280 to 420 ppm (parts per million) over the past 150 years.
V1C12L2:
Half of the CO2 we emit every year is absorbed by carbon sinks: 
 - 1/4 by vegetation via photosynthesis 
 - 1/4 by the oceans 
 The remaining 1/2 stays in the atmosphere.
V1C13L2: The greenhouse effect is a naturally occurring phenomenon. In fact, water vapor is the most common GHG. Without the greenhouse effect, the planet would be 59°F (33°C) colder! However, CO2 and other GHGs related to human activities are exacerbing the natural greenhouse effect which is warming the climate.
V1C14L2: This graph explains where the energy accumulating on Earth due to radiative forcing (the change in the energy balance) goes. This additional energy warms up the oceans, melts ice, dissipates into the ground, and warms up the atmosphere.
V1C15L2: Radiative forcing represents the difference between the energy that reaches the Earth and the energy that is released every second. Think of it as the relative change in the earth's energy balance. Radiative forcing is currently 2.8 W/m² (Watts per meter squared). +3.8 W/m² come from the greenhouse effect and -1 W/m² reduction caused by aerosols.
V1C16L2: Almost all glaciers are receding, and hundreds of them have already disappeared. Glaciers are significant because they contribute to regulate the supply of fresh water.
V1C17L2: Oceans absorb 91% of the energy accumulated on Earth. Water expands as it warms.
V1C18L2: Melting sea ice does not cause the sea's level to rise (just as melting ice cubes melting in a drink do not cause a glass to overflow).
V1C19L2: Greenland and Antarctica are ice sheets (or continental glaciers). If they were to completely melt, they would cause the sea level to rise by 23 feet (7 meters) from Greenland's melting and 177 feet (54 meters) for Antarctica's melting. During the last ice age, ice sheets were much larger and the sea level was 390 feet (120 meters) lower than today.
V1C1L2: This is where it all begins….
V1C20L2: Warmer water and warmer air result in increased evaporation at the surface of the ocean. This makes more clouds and thus more rainfall. On the other hand, an increased evaporation over land dries out the soil.
V1C21L2: The average air temperature at the surface of the Earth has increased by 2.2°F (1.2°C) since 1900. Possible future emission scenarios predict that this increase will reach between 2.7°F (1.5°C) and 9°F (5°C) by 2100. During the last ice age, 20,000 years ago, the average air temperature was only 9°F (5°C) lower than today, and it took 10,000 years for the Earth to warm up!
V1C22L2: Since 1900, sea levels have risen by 7.9 in (20 cm). This is caused by the ocean water expanding as it heats up, combined with melt water from glaciers and ice sheets.
V1C22L3: Global mean sea level rise from 1900
V1C23L2: When the pH of the ocean drops, it becomes harder to make calcium carbonate, which is important for making shells.
V1C24L2: When CO2 dissolves in the ocean, it turns into acid ions. This makes the oceans more acidic, and the pH drops.
V1C24L3: Ocean acidification according to SSP scenarios (pH)
V1C25L2: The causes of biodiversity loss are: the destruction of the habitats, over harvesting of wild species, pollution, climate change and the introduction of nonnative invasive species. These changes in the living conditions of species (e.g. temperature and water cycle) force species to migrate and to adapt their way of life.
V1C26L2: Disruption of the water cycle can both increase and decrease rainfall. More rain can cause rivers to flood. Urbanization (concrete and asphalt surfaces) and very dry soil (due to drought) worsen the flooding because the rainwater runs off.
V1C27L2: Pteropods and coccolithophores are at the base of the ocean food chain. If they are driven to extinction, all marine biodiversity will be threatened. Warming waters and overfishing also threaten ocean life.
V1C28L2: Some animals carry diseases. Global warming causes them to migrate, possibly reaching populations without immunity to those diseases.
V1C29L2: Pteropods are a type of zooplankton and coccolithophores a type of phytoplankton. These organisms have shells made of calcium carbonate.
V1C2L2: Industry uses fossil fuels and electricity. It accounts for 40% of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
V1C30L2: The disruption of the water cycle can both increase and decrease rainfall. A lack of rain can cause drought. Droughts are likely to become more frequent in the future.
V1C31L2: Freshwater resources are affected by changes in rainfall and by the melting of glaciers, which plays a role in regulating the flow of rivers.
V1C32L2: Food production can be affected by temperature, droughts, extreme weather events, and flooding (e.g. the Nile Delta).
V1C33L2: Hurricanes, cyclones, typhoons, and atmospheric waves bring wind, waves, and low pressure conditions. A 1 hectopascal pressure drop causes a 0.4 inch of sea level rise. Therefore these conditions can cause coastal flooding, which is already aggravated by sea level rise.
V1C34L2: Hurricanes (cyclones) draw on the energy from warm water at the ocean surface. Climate change is making them more powerful.
V1C35L2: Wildfires and forest fires start and spread more easily during droughts and heatwaves. They emit CO2 in the same way as deforestation. This creates a feedback loop.
V1C36L2: Heatwaves will become more frequent and more intense. The combination of high temperature and humidity can create deadly conditions for humans. The number of days when these fatal weather conditions occur is expected to increase.
V1C37L2: Hunger and famine can be caused by lower agricultural yields and by the loss of marine biodiversity.
V1C38L2: Hunger, migration of carriers of disease, heatwaves and armed conflicts can have a negative effect on human health.
V1C39L2: The consequences of climate change will inevitably make some ecosystems uninhabitable for humans, and will force people to relocate.
V1C3L2: Houses  and commercial buildings use fossil fuels and electricity. It accounts for 20% of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
V1C40L2: Let's not allow it to end this way....
V1C41L2: Permafrost refers to permanently frozen ground. As it thaws, it is releasing methane and CO2 into the atmosphere. These gases come from the decomposition of previously frozen organic matter. Melting permafrost thus creates an amplifying feedback loop.
V1C42L2: Climate change reinforces social and economic inequalities: between individuals, between countries, and between generations. To prevent these inequalities from getting worse, we must ensure climate policies are fair and equitable.
V1C4L2: The transportation sector is highly dependent on oil. It accounts for 15% of greenhouse gas emissions.
V1C5L2: Fossil fuels are coal, oil, and natural gas. They are used mainly in buildings, transportation, and industry. They emit CO2 when burned.
V1C5L4: Billions of tons of CO2 per year
V1C6L2:
Deforestation is defined as cutting down or burning trees beyond the ability of the forest to regrow. 80% of deforestation is driven by agricultural expansion.
In addition to emitting CO2, deforestation destroys the natural habitats of many species.
V1C7L2: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the main anthropogenic greenhouse gas (emissions caused by human activities). These emissions come from the burning of fossil fuels and from deforestation.
V1C8L2: Agriculture is responsible for emissions of CO2 (through deforestation), methane (from cattle and rice fields), and nitrous oxide (from fertilizers). In total, globally, agriculture is responsible for 25% of greenhouse gases emissions.
V1C999L2: The Climate Fresk was developed by Cédric Ringenbach. Its distribution is managed by the non-profit organisation 'La Fresque du Climat'.
V1C999L3:
In order to become a Climate Fresk facilitator, one must first participate in a Climate Fresk workshop and then complete a facilitator training.
The usage license is Creative Commons BY-NC-ND for non-professional use.
V1C999L4:
Any commercial use or use internally within a company (meaning without the facilitation of professional Climate Fresk facilitator) is subject to usage rights. The full license is available here: fresqueduclimat.org/licence.
Usage rights must be paid at: http://fresqueduclimat.org/droits.
V1C999L6: L’association La Fresque du Climat (the Climate Fresk organization) http://fresqueduclimat.org
V1C999L91: Printed in France on 100% recycled paper
V1C9L2: CO2 is not the only Greenhouse Gas (GHG). There is also methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O) (which come largely from agriculture), as well as a few others, and a few gases from other sources.
